description: From Latin assertus, perfect passive participle of asserō (“declare someone free or a slave by laying hands upon him; hence free from, protect, defend; lay claim to, assert, declare”), from ad (“to”) + serō (“join, range in a row”).

entries.meaning: (computer science) an assertion; a section of source code which tests whether an expected condition is true.

verbs.description: assert (third-person singular simple present asserts, present participle asserting, simple past and past participle asserted)

entries.meaning: To declare with assurance or plainly and strongly; to state positively.
examples: He would often assert that there was life on other planets.

entries.meaning: To use or exercise and thereby prove the existence of.
examples: Salman Rushdie has asserted his right to be identified as the author of this work.

entries.meaning: To maintain or defend, as a cause or a claim, by words or measures; to vindicate a claim or title to
examples: to assert our rights and liberties

entries.meaning: (reflexive) To insist on the legitimacy of one's rights, opinion, etc; not to allow oneself to be dismissed; to ensure that one is taken into consideration; to make oneself respected; to be assertive.
examples: Since going to therapy, I've found it much easier to assert myself.

entries.meaning: (programming) To specify that a condition or expression is true at a certain point in the code.
(electronics) To set a signal on a line using a voltage or electric current.
